description:
Over the past few decades, Earth’s changing climate has driven a huge increase in the area burned by wildfires. Warmer, drier weather in some locations has increased the risk of wildfires, which are one of the most dangerous natural hazards that humans face. In this module, students explore key variables that influence the spread and severity of wildfires, consider the impacts of fire and smoke damage to increasingly populated areas, and make predictions about how climate change may affect future wildfires.

In this five-activity module, students will address the guiding question: How will wildfire risks and impacts change over the next 100 years?
title: Cypress_Automated_Wildfire_Module

activities.description: In this introductory activity, students investigate the phenomena of wildfires in the western part of the United States. They explore real-world data on the frequency of wildfires and the number of acres burned over time. Students connect their ideas about the trends in the data to what might be causing the fluctuations. Students also begin to consider what makes wildfires hazardous and how they impact people and their communities.

embeddables.content: Wildfires are a natural phenomenon that happen every year all around the world. Sometimes wildfires can grow very large and out of control. They can spread close to places where people work and live. As a wildfire burns and spreads, the skies turn red and are filled with smoke. Wildfires can be deadly to the people, ecosystems, and animals in their path.

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"framing","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"**Welcome to the Wildfire Module Teacher Edition! You can open and close this tip, and other teacher tips in this module by clicking on the orange "Framing the Activity" button above.** Fires have been raging around the world, destroying homes and burning up millions of acres. As the world experiences extreme heat waves and droughts with more frequency due to climate change, firefighters will continue to struggle to bring these fires under control. These fires sharpen the call to take climate change more seriously and explore the role it plays in the development of these natural hazards. Climate change plays an important role; warmer temperatures means drier vegetation, which acts as perfect kindling for fires. Hot, dry winds also help spread wildfire. It is the goal of this module to help students build an understanding of the factors that influence the rate of spread and intensity of wildfires--factors that are amplified as a result of changing climate. In addition, we will provide students with the opportunity to consider the factors that transform a natural phenomenon into a natural hazard. Students will explore the risks, hazards, and impacts of wildfires on people and their communities. Finally, they will consider the long-term effects of fire suppression and the environmental impacts of wildfires to important ecosystems. In line with the NGSS (see Wildfire Module Standards Alignment), this module engages students in the use of evidence gathered from exploration with the Wildfire Explorer, a model we developed to investigate variables that influence the spread and impacts of a wildfire on communities and environments in its path. Student work throughout the module is driven by the guiding question: **How will wildfire risks and impacts change over the next 100 years?** ","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. embeddables.content:
Scientists use models to study wildfires. In this module, you will use a wildfire model to investigate the factors that affect wildfires in order to answer the framing question:

How will wildfire risks and impacts change over the next 100 years? 

To answer this question, you first need to learn more about wildfires like where they start and how they spread, what hazards wildfires bring, who is at risk from wildfires, and how these hazards impact people and their communities.

embeddables.content:
First, it is important to realize that wildfires have occured naturally for thousands of years. Some ecosystems have plants and animals that are adapted to living through wildfires. Some even need wildfires to survive!

One way that scientists study wildfires is to study trees that are hundreds of years old. When they look at tree rings, they can see evidence of wildfires in the past. In some areas, wildfires occurred as frequently as once every 10-15 years! For example, the photo below shows burn marks from five different fires.

pages.name: Wildfire History in the United States

embeddables.content:
Even though wildfires are natural, they are not always welcomed.

The largest wildfire in the United States was the Great Fire of 1910. The fire burned for 2 days in August that year and killed 87 firefighters, completely destroyed several towns, and burned many trees which were to be used as lumber. 

In just one weekend, this fire burned three million acres in North Idaho and Western Montana and spread to Washington state and even up to Canada. This means the Great Fire was the size of 2.3 million football fields, or the entire land area of the state of Connecticut!

embeddables.authored_state: {"version":1,"scaling":"fitWidth","url":"https://has-production.s3.amazonaws.com/resources/geohazard-wildfire/Wallace_Idaho_1910_fire.jpg","caption":"Wallace, Idaho was destroyed by wildfire in 1910. Here, the city is being rebuilt in 1915.","credit":"National Photo Company - U.S. Library of Congress","creditLink":"http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3c00916 ","altText":"This is a black and white photo of Wallace, Idaho. It was destroyed by wildfire in 1910. In this photo, the city is being rebuilt in 1915."}

{"version":1,"questionType":"open_response","prompt":"

The Great Fire happened when people were migrating from the east coast to the west coast. Many new towns were built along the way in forests and previously untouched wilderness.

\n

Why do you think it was important for people to control wildfires during that time?

"}

{"version":1,"questionType":"open_response","prompt":"

In the early 1900s, the United States government created the Forest Service. They decided it was best to put out fires right away rather than letting them burn. Putting out wildfires as quickly as possible is called Fire Suppression. 

\n

How do you think forests change when wildfires are put out quickly for many years?

"}

Many people traveled through these previously forested areas, so keeping them safe and free of fires might have encouraged more people to migrate.","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

pages.name: Are wildfires burning more now than in the past?

embeddables.content:
Wildfires occur all over the world. Recently, in the United States, there have been some of the most intense and damaging wildfires of all time. Are these large fires the new normal? Will we continue to see wildfires like this over the next few decades? Scientists are thinking about these questions and this module will help you think about these questions, too.

Some areas are more prone to wildfire than others. In the United States, they occur most frequently in the western states like California, Montana, and Idaho. The map below highlights the states that are considered part of the western U.S. The graph shows the amount of acres that wildfires have burned in this region. Examine the graph and answer the questions below.

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"teacherTip","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"This is the first time students are asked about certainty in their explanations. In any scientific argument in the claim-evidence-reasoning format, there is room for uncertainty based on limitations in the data presented as well as other unknown factors. At different points in the module, students will be presented with data or are asked to generate data using the Wildfire Explorer model. They are then asked to make a claim, write an explanation, and then rate their level of uncertainty. Sometimes, they are asked to explain their uncertainty. Other times, they are asked to think of ways to improve their certainty. If students struggle with these questions, take some time to discuss the ways that explanations in science evolve based on new data. For more tips, see our guide to Teaching Uncertainty and Risk. These types of questions are particularly interesting when thinking about natural hazards. **Wildfire risk is inherently uncertain and impacts depend on multiple scientific, situational, and personal factors.**","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

embeddables.content:
Wildfires can start naturally by lightning. However, about 85% of wildfires are accidentally started by people! Faulty electrical wires, campfires, and cigarettes often provide the spark that starts a fire. Below is a map of wildfires that were burning in December 2017 in Southern California.

One reason why these fires were so dangerous was because they were close to major cities. Below is a map of Los Angeles County. Around 10 million people live in this part of California and were at risk when the fires approached. Los Angeles County is very diverse, with people of many different backgrounds, ages, and income levels.

embeddables.content:
Scientists use many different tools and models to monitor wildfires as they form and spread. Predicting where and when a wildfire could reach a city can help people and communities prepare for the hazards that wildfires bring.

When a wildfire comes near an area where people work or live, that area is considered at risk of the damage that a wildfire can bring.

pages.name: What happens when wildfires come too close?

embeddables.content:
You have now seen that there is an upward trend in the number of acres wildfires burn. Scientists agree! They have noticed this trend and are studying the wildfires of the past in order to help predict wildfires in the future.

In this module, you will learn more about the scientific factors that influence wildfires and consider the risks and impacts of wildfires to people and their communities both now and in the years to come.

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"An important concept that forms the basis and motivation for this module is the understanding of hazards, impacts, and risk. These three words will be repeated throughout the module. Students should practice using these terms and distinguish between them. 

**A hazard is anything that has the potential to harm people or the environment.** The two hazards of wildfires are smoke and fire.

**An impact is an outcome of a hazard.** Impacts can be positive or negative. Negative impacts of fire are buildings burning down, ecosystems being destroyed, and many others. Positive impacts include new vegetation growth and elimination of invasive species.

**Risk is the likelihood of a hazard to cause a specific impact.** For example, southern California is at a high risk (degree of likelihood) of fire (the hazard) burning down homes (impact) when there is severe drought in the area. Risk involves some level of uncertainty with prediction because we can never exactly know what is going to happen.","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"discussionPoints","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"*This is a great place to stop and elicit students’ initial ideas about the hazards and risks of wildfires.* This activity has introduced the socio-economic issues that arise when communities prepare for wildfires and other natural disasters. This topic will be visited again later in the module. However, because of the complexity of this issue the module will only address a few of these issues. At this point, eliciting students’ initial ideas about risks to different populations is important. Both preparing for wildfires (buying supplies and staying put) and evacuating (access to reliable transportation and having a safe place to go) can be expensive. Asking questions like, “Why is it more difficult for older people or sick people to prepare for a wildfire?” and "Why is it more difficult for people from low socioeconomic communities to evacuate during a wildfire?" will generate rich class discussions. For tips on discussing natural hazards from a personal and social perspective, please see our guide to Addressing Socioscientific Issues in the Classroom. We suggest you use an off-line tool called a Summary Table to record student ideas. Summary Tables can be used individually by students to track their thinking as they progress toward an explanatory model of the phenomenon and guiding question: **How will wildfire risks and impacts change over the next 100 years? ** A Summary Table can also be used to record student ideas in a public place, such as a poster or a projected online document shared at the front of the room. (Please read these brief instructions on how to use Summary Tables.)","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. activities.description: Students are introduced to the Fire Triangle, which contains the three elements necessary for a fire to occur: oxygen, fuel, and heat. Students use the Wildfire Explorer simulation and work with variables like drought level, wind speed and direction, and terrain to discover how these factors influence the speed and extent of wildfire spread.

embeddables.content: Due to the many wildfires in the United States and beyond, people have become more aware of fire season, the time of the year when most wildfires occur. Fire season in the United States typically starts in August and continues through December. During these months, people living close to where wildfires have occured in the past closely monitor the news, watch to see where fires are located, where they are moving, and how far smoke travels.

","defaultAnswer":"","required":false,"questionType":"open_response","hint":""}

embeddables.content: During the 2018 wildfire season, a wildfire in California called the Camp Fire started due to a spark from a broken power line. This wildfire burned for 17 days, spread over 153,336 acres, and destroyed 18,804 homes and other buildings. The Camp Fire is the deadliest and most destructive wildfire in California history. To the right is an animation of the Camp Fire to show where it started and how wind affected its spread.

embeddables.content:
Wildfires are a naturally occurring phenomenon that have been happening as long as there have been things to burn. People have been avoiding, and sometimes harnessing, the power of wildfires for thousands of years.

Recently, technological advances have allowed more intense study of widfires. This has led to a better understanding of the causes, spread, and methods to control wildfires.

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"The Fire Triangle is a simple way of understanding the interdependent ingredients needed for a fire.   

**Heat** is responsible for the initial ignition of fire and is also needed to maintain the fire. Heat allows fire to spread by drying out and preheating nearby fuel and warming surrounding air.

**Fuel** is any kind of material that is combustible and is often characterized by its moisture content, its quantity, and how it is spread over a landscape. The moisture content determines how easily the fuel will burn.

**Oxygen** is required for fires to burn. Oxygen supports the chemical process when fires burn. Wind replenishes oxygen. 
","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

pages.name: Not all wildfires behave the same

embeddables.content:
Not all wildfires behave in the same way. Fire behavior depends on several factors! Each year, in the late summer and fall, weather conditions of high heat, low humidity, and consistent winds bring the ideal conditions for wildfires.

Long term weather patterns, called climate, also play a large role in the way fires behave. For example, when it doesn't rain for many months or years, it is called a drought. When there is a drought that means trees and other vegetation dry out because they do not have enough water. Scientists describe dry plants as having a low moisture content.

Now you will investigate how drought conditions affect the spread of wildfires using the Wildfire Explorer, which is similar to the models scientists use to investigate wildfires.

The amount of moisture is represented in the Wildfire Explorer by the drought level. Click the Terrain Setup button to adjust the drought level. Then, place a spark in each zone and run the model. Be sure to open the graph as you run the model.

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"Student answers will vary.

Students may mention that drought, wind speed, and wind direction are all unpredictable variables during a wildfire. Many areas in the western United States have been under drought conditions for years. But large precipitation events and increased snowfall can change that situation. During a wildfire, if the wind shifts direction, then the wildfire will change direction. When a wildfire encounters more fuel, then its speed can drastically change.
","teacherTip":"It is important for students to understand how these factors influence wildfire spread so they can build on this knowledge moving forward in the module. Encourage students to continue experimenting with the model to connect cause and effects between the factors and fire spread. 

The relationships between these factors and fire spread can be summed up as follows: 
- A higher drought level causes fire to spread faster. Dryer fuels more readily catch on fire and burn faster than fuels with higher moisture. 
- Higher wind speeds cause fire to spread faster. The wind pushes the fire forward and can spread embers and spark ahead of the fire. 
- The fire spreads fastest in the direction of the wind.","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

embeddables.content:
Wind and drought aren't the only factors that affect wildfire spread! 

On this page, the Wildfire Explorer is set with three different terrains: mountains, hills, and plains. You will conduct two investigations with this model. The first investigation will look at the effect of different terrains on wildfire spread. The second investigation will look at how the location of a spark in the mountains affects wildfire spread.

Before you run the model, place one spark in each of the three zones. (Don't make any other changes to the model setup!) Compare how fast the fire spreads in each terrain type. Then, answer the questions below.

Don't forget to open the graph while you run the model!

embeddables.content:
On the previous page, you observed how a wildfire spreads fastest in the mountainous terrain. Also, you noticed how a fire started at the bottom of a mountain spreads more quickly than a fire started at the top of a mountain.

Watch the video below of a matchstick experiment. Note that there is no wind in the room and there is no sound in the video.

How does the experiment help you think about why fire spreads differently uphill compared to downhill?

embeddables.content:
In this activity, you have learned how the drought level, wind, and terrain affects wildfire spread. Using what you now know, examine the animation of the 2018 Camp Fire in California again. 

The environmental conditions immediately leading up to the Camp Fire were as follows:

  • An unusually dry fall (very little rain)
  • 95% of vegetation was considered to be at "medium drought" level
  • 10% humidity (very low moisture in the air)
  • High winds (25-30 mph)

Run the animation again and think about the factors listed above.

Do they help explain why wildfires occur in some areas more than others? We suggest you use an off-line tool called a Summary Table to record student ideas. Summary Tables can be used individually by students to track their thinking as they progress toward an explanatory model of the phenomenon and guiding question: **How will wildfire risks and impacts change over the next 100 years? ** A Summary Table can also be used to record student ideas in a public place, such as a poster or a projected online document shared at the front of the room. activities.description: Students investigate how wildfires behave when fueled with different types and sizes of vegetation. They also explore how the moisture level of vegetation can affect the spread of wildfire. Finally, students consider how the public policy of fire suppression has resulted in unintended consequences and risk to people living and working in wildfire-prone areas.

embeddables.content:
Wildfires have been in the news every summer for years now, showing pictures and videos of tremendous blazes and firefighters battling the flames. Were wildfires always this bad? Are wildfires getting worse? If yes, what is causing wildfires to become worse?

Below is a graph of the number of wildfires in the United States and the number of acres burned by wildfires in the United States from 1991 to 2020. The red line shows the number of wildfires and the grey shaded area shows the number of acres burned. Use this graph to answer the questions below.

The red line represents the number of fires. The grey shaded area represents the number of acres burned.","creditLink":"https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/IF10244.pdf","creditLinkDisplayText":"NICC Wildland Fire Summary and Statistics annual reports, 2021.","allowLightbox":true}

embeddables.content:
Models can help scientists investigate the factors that might contribute to the increase in large wildfires.

In the Wildfire Explorer, you have investigated the environmental conditions that contribute to the spread of wildfires like wind speed and direction, terrain, and drought level. You can also investigate how different types of vegetation can affect the speed at which wildfires spread. There are three common types of vegetation in the model: grassland, shrubland, and forests. You can see a picture of these three types of vegetation to the right. 

Use Wildfire Explorer to compare the speed of the spread of fire with these vegetation types side by side. Run an experiment by changing the vegetation type in each zone. Don't forget to open the graph. Make sure to compare all three vegetation types!

{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"discussionPoints","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":false,"content":"As students complete this page check in to make sure the students are making sense of what they are seeing. Have students discuss their answers and justifications to question 6 with a partner and then share their ideas to the class as a whole.

Use the following common teacher **Talk Moves** to push for understanding: “Can you say more?”, “What do you mean when you say ___?”, “Who agrees/disagrees with what s/he said?”, and “Does anyone have another idea?”. This is a good opportunity for you to generate a public list of student ideas on the board or a large piece of paper. You can return to this list in the future to assess any changes in thinking or increase sophistication in their explanations. It is important to keep in mind that this is not a time to evaluate answers or direct responses.

If students need prompting, ask:

**How might wildfires in the Great Plains affect people living in other parts of the country?** 

In the case of the Great Plains, if farms, livestock, grain, and other crops are burnt, the farmers will suffer financially. In addition, there will be no food to ship to other areas of the country.

embeddables.content:
In the beginning of this module, you learned that in the early 1900s, the US Forest Service began putting out all wildfires as quickly as possible. As a result of this fire suppression, many forests, grasslands, and shrublands have become overgrown.

After many years, the forest floors have accumulated tons of dead debris from fallen trees and other plants. The picture below shows a forest in which a fire has not burned through in many years.

{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"discussionPoints","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":false,"content":"Ask students if they can think of different ways that humans change the outcome of wildfires. They should think about both positive and negative ways. The following list should give you some ideas to prompt students, if they are stuck.

**Think about the Fire Triangle; what ways do you think human migration, settlement, and land management has potential to impact wildfires?** These impacts may be positive or negative. Use the following list to help prompt students as needed. Ask the students to make an initial claim about the value of fire suppression. Be sure to emphasize supporting claims with evidence and that no claim is wrong.


* Wildfires can start when lightning strikes but research shows that people start a lot more fires than lightning does. 


* Human caused ignitions of fires tend to be near the wildland and urban interface increasing the risk where human development meets the wildlife area.


* Land use and forest management affect wildfire risk. Past fire suppression and forest management practices have led to a build-up of flammable fuel wood which increases wildfire risks. 


* Climate change causes warmer, drier conditions in some areas resulting in increased drought and a longer fire season.


* The risk to people and property from wildfires is on the rise because of the increasing number of homes and businesses being built in and near wildfire prone areas. 


* Controlled fires are intentionally lit by land management professionals. They burn off leaf litter and underbrush that would otherwise fuel bigger wildfires. Controlled fires also help germinate the seeds of many tree species. Some people do not like these types of fires because they fear that the fire will get loose and these fires can be very smoky.","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

embeddables.content:
The speed of spread of a wildfire is only one of the measures of how severe a wildfire is. Another important measure of wildfire is the intensity of the fire. Fire intensity measures the amount of heat a wildfire creates as it burns. The Wildfire Explorer shows fire intensity with color. The red color at the fire front represents the most intense part of the wildfire. 

Use the model to investigate which vegetation type burns most intensely. Make sure to experiment with all four vegetation types: grass, shrubs, forest, and forest with suppression. Open the graph when you run the model.

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"The intensity of a fire refers to the amount of heat that the fire puts out. Very intense fires occur when there is a large amount of fuel burning simultaneously. In forests that have experienced years of fire suppression, there are a lot of fallen branches and entire trees on the forest floor. When this much fuel ignites, the fire burns hotter. It also takes longer for the fuel to be used up. Intense fires tend to burn down entire forests rather than just scaring trees. In contrast, with a smaller surface area to volume ratio, grass fires use up their fuel quickly and also move quickly. Grass fires, though destructive, are less intense. If a grass fire moved past a large tree, it may leave a scar but would likely pass prior to burning down the entire tree. Shrubs are an interesting vegetation as well. They have enough fuel to burn intensely, especially if they are dry, and they are small enough and close enough together to also spread quickly. Learn more about wildfire fuel.","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

embeddables.content:
Fire suppression was originally intended to help protect people’s homes, businesses, and the growing need for trees for lumber as the population of the US expanded west.

It worked well in the short term, as the number of fires and number of acres burned went down in the middle of the 1900s. But now, 100 years after fire suppression started, it may be making wildfires worse! How will wildfire suppression affect fires in the coming years?

Very recently, firefighters have started to use controlled, or prescribed burns, to clear out dead debris on the forest floor as show on the bottom photo.

Prescribed burns are small fires that are set on purpose in specific areas, in a controlled and safe way, to remove dead vegetation.

activities.description: Students explore the hazards and risks caused by wildfires. They use the Wildfire Explorer to consider what factors make wildfires more or less of a risk to people in different communities. Students also explore how wildfires are contained, and how people can mitigate the risks of wildfires to both their home and their larger community.

embeddables.content:
In December of 2017, there were many active wildfires in southern California. The map below shows four of the fires that were burning at this time. These fires brought dangerous hazards to the people living in this area. A hazard is anything that has the potential to cause harm. 

Because of these hazards, the towns around the fires were at great risk. Risk is the likelihood of loss, damage, or impact from the hazards of the wildfires.

More specifically, you can see certain towns, like Thousand Oaks, were surrounded on three sides by burning fires.

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"Correct! All of these are hazards of wildfires.","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"","teacherTip":"Mudslides are a secondary hazard of wildfires. When fires burn down trees, grasses, and other vegetation, the roots of those plants no longer hold soil in place. If there is any rain following a wildfire, it can easily dislodge large chunks of soil and earth and slide it down a slope. Mudslides can happen in the days or months after a wildfire, but also years later if not enough vegetation grows back to hold the soil in place.","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"framing","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"**The goal of this activity is to explore the hazards and risks caused by wildfires.** The first few activities asked students to explore the factors that impact the spread of wildfires. In this activity students will use the model to consider what factors make wildfires more or less of a risk to people in different communities. They will also explore how people can mitigate the risks of wildfires both during an active wildfire event as well as while planning for the future. As students go through the activity, it is important to emphasize that scientists are actively studying wildfire behavior for multiple reasons. In addition to the goal of understanding wildfire as a scientific phenomenon, considering ways to reduce the impact of wildfires on people and their communities is important. New technology is being developed to track wildfires in real time and share information quickly, which can help those at risk make informed choices such as when to evacuate. For more tips, see our guide to Teaching Uncertainty and Risk. ","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. embeddables.content:
Wildfires become natural hazards when they bring fire and smoke to regions where people live. In this activity, we will investigate risk using the WIldfire Explorer model.

Below is a snapshot of the Wildfire Explorer. Three towns are located on the map, two are in the mountains and one is in the plains. The wind is blowing to the northeast and the fire has started at the spark.

Is it possible to estimate the level of risk to each town given the initial conditions?

{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"Wildfires become natural hazards when they bring fire and smoke to regions where people live. The following describes how we are approaching concepts around hazards and risk in this module:

* Wildfires become **natural hazards** when they bring fire and smoke to regions where people live or have various economic, ecological, or societal interests. 
* Wildfires cause **damages and losses** (negative impacts) to humans and the environment.
* Assessing **risk involves uncertainty**. 
* **Human actions** can increase or decrease short-term and long-term wildfire risks. ","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

embeddables.content:
Environmental conditions can detemine which towns are at the highest risk when a wildfire starts. Some environmental conditions don't change while the fire is burning like the terrain, the type of vegetation, and the current drought level. However, other conditions can change suddenly and frequently such as wind speed and direction. How might wind speed and direction affect a town's risk of wildfire?

On this page, you will use the Wildfire Explorer model to make forecasts for three towns in a hilly area.

embeddables.content:
Wildfires can start naturally or by people being careless. Either way, once it starts, there is a risk that it will bring severe hazards to people and their communities. Wildfire brings two immediate hazards: fire and smoke. 

Wildfires burn everything in their path. Trees, houses, telephone poles, shopping centers, and bridges can all be consumed by fire. In 2018, more than 25,000 buildings throughout the US were destroyed due to wildfires. This includes 18,137 residences and 229 commercial buildings. Flames can travel up to 14 miles per hour, faster than most people can run.

When wildfires burn they produce smoke. Wildfire smoke is a mixture of gases and fine particles from burning trees and other plant materials. 

Look at the pictures below and answer the questions.

embeddables.content:
In wildfire news, there are often stories about brave firefighters who put themselves in harm's way to save people, houses, and land. The name "firefighter" is a little misleading, though. Many wildfires are too intense and too large to be put out by just throwing water on them. Instead, firefighters must work to contain the fire.

To contain a fire means to surround it and put barriers in place so that it cannot expand further. If a fire is 100 percent contained, that means firefighters were able to complete a perimeter around it and stop it from spreading. So, maybe "firefighters" should be called "fire containers" instead!

Two methods that firefighters use to help contain wildfires are firelines and helitacks. Fire lines are strips of land that have been cleared of vegetation in order to stop fire spread. Helitacks are helicopters or airplanes that fly over fires and drop water or fire retardant to douse the flames.

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"It takes time to dig a fireline, so it makes sense that you cannot draw as many as you want continuously. Also, the helicopters need to keep refilling with water every time they drop water on the ground, and that takes time too.","teacherTip":"Real teams of firefighters, called **Hot Shots**, are deployed into often rough and difficult terrain to dig fire lines. When building a fire line, all fuels are removed and the surface is scraped to mineral soil on a strip between 6 inches and 3 feet wide, depending upon the type of vegetation and slope. The cleared line needs to be wide enough to prevent smoldering, burning, or spotting by embers blowing or rolling across. Fire lines are usually dug wider at the head of the fire than along the flanks, as that is where fire burns the most intensely. **For more information on fire lines,** go to the U.S. Park Service website and U.S. Forest Service website . **For more information on helitacks,** see the U.S. Forest Service website.","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

Helitacks can douse flames and wet vegetation, but an intense fire will not be extinguished by even a well placed helitack. Helitacks are often used to suppress fire in areas where firefighters need to work building firelines.","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

Since the line is plotting burned area versus time, the slope of the lines represents the rate of spread of the wildfire. A steeper slope means the fire is spreading rapidly, while a lower slope means the fire is spreading slowly. **An effective mitigation technique should slow the spread, which means it should result in a decrease in slope on the graph.**","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"teacherTip","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"On this page, two ways to mitigate fires are introduced in the Wildfire Explorer model, **fire lines** and **helitacks**. Both can only be used after a fire has already started. 

To use a **fire line**, click on the icon in the toolbar. Note that the model will pause and the fire will stop spreading when you click the fire line button. Move the icon to the map and click and drag to draw a fire line. Once you have placed it, you can move both sides of the fire line to position it exactly where you want. Click “Start” to restart the model and continue fire spread. The fire line button will be greyed out for a couple seconds after use, to simulate the time that it takes to build a fire line.

To use a **helitack**, click on the helicopter button in the toolbar. The fire will not stop spreading when a helitack is used! Move the cursor, now the helicopter icon, to the area on the map you want to douse with water. Click the mouse to drop the water. The spot where it has landed on the map will turn light blue. This is to signify that the area where the water has been put has decreased the drought level in that spot (if it was dropped in a medium drought zone, that spot will now behave as if it is a mild drought zone). There is also a delay between uses of a helitack, but the wait time is less than that of building a fire line.
","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

embeddables.content:
Firefighters work day and night to contain the spread of wildfires, especially when they burn near communities. Individual homeowners can take steps to reduce the risk of their personal property burning down and reduce the fuel available to the fire.

Below is a graphic from FEMA, the United States Federal Emergency Management Agency, on how to limit damage to homes and other buildings.

Don't forget the three sides of the Fire Triangle are Heat, Fuel, and Oxygen.

embeddables.content:
Let's put all the ideas we have learned about in this activity together to investigate which town is at the highest risk from the new Concord Wildfire that just broke out. Each of the towns in the model has a similar sized population.

Communities experience a different level of risk from wildfires depending on where they are located and the environmental conditions in their area. Using what you have learned about wildfire hazards, impact, and mitigation techniques, estimate the risk for each town near the spreading Concord Wildfire below. 

Look at the Wildfire Explorer but don't run it yet! Look at the environmental conditions in each zone. You will make a prediction before you run the model.

activities.description:
The future of wildfire risk is complex and is being actively researched by scientists. In this final activity, students investigate how climate change correlates to projected changes in wildfire frequency, intensity, risk, and impact. Students model wildfire occurrence in a future that includes more extensive human development in wildlands as well as extreme heat and drought. This activity also introduces concepts related to changes in ecosystems and forest succession due to wildfires.

By the end of this activity, students should be better able to answer the guiding question: How will wildfire risks and impacts change over the next 100 years?
activities.name: Wildfires in the Future

pages.name: Back to the future of wildfires

embeddables.content:
Scientists have been tracking changes in global climate for many years. They have found that temperatures have been rising over the past few decades. But climate change isn't just about temperature! The amount of rain and snow (precipitation) in certain regions of the U.S. is also changing. 

The maps below show data on temperature and drought. On the left, the map shows the average temperature change in each state from 1970 to 2021. The darker the red, the higher the temperature increase.

Record-breaking heat waves are often accompanied by extreme drought. The map on the right shows drought levels during a heat wave in June 2021.

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"Students should notice that all western states saw higher than normal temperatures in the summer of 2015. Compared to the projection of wildfire risk, it is clear that there is some correlation between the two. ","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"","teacherTip":"There are locations on the map that are not perfectly aligned. If students are stuck on this, ask them why they think this is. Ask,  “Are there any places where temperature in 2015 was lower than normal but the wildfire risk is projected to be higher?” (Wisconsin and Michigan fit this description).  Some reasons for the difference may be because of precipitation, there may be drought in some areas where the temperatures aren't significantly higher but the vegetation is much drier.","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

embeddables.content:
According to the U.S. National Climate Assessment of 2014, "Increased heat, drought, and insect outbreaks, all linked to climate change, have increased wildfires." You have investigated how heat and drought can increase the fuel from wildfires. In addition, dry vegetation is more at risk of being attacked by insects, which can kill trees and plants resulting in more fuel for wildfires.

Watch the video below to learn more about the impacts that climate change is having on wildfires.

The video on the prior page suggested that models, such as Wildfire Explorer, can be helpful for thinking about how wildfires might behave in the future. You can use the Wildfire Explorer model to investigate how climate change could impact the spread of wildfires and fire containment efforts. 

You can now set the Wildfire Explorer model to have a Severe Drought in each zone. First, set all the zones to Severe Drought and run the model. Then, try building fire lines and using helitacks to contain the fire and save each town that is at risk. You can experiment with the other variables in the model like wind and vegetation type.

Can wildfires be contained by firelines and helitacks in extremely dry conditions?

embeddables.content:
Wildfires burn almost everything in their path. People and their communities are not the only ones at risk of wildfire. Entire forests can be wiped out, including all of the trees, grasses, and especially the dead plant litter on the ground. Animal habitats can be destroyed as well, making the impacted area a desolate and uninhabitable wasteland.

Life finds a way, though. After a fire, grasses are the first to grow back. Smaller shrubs come back after grasses, and finally tree saplings can begin to grow. Animals slowly return as their food becomes available, and a place that was once desolate becomes a thriving ecosystem again.

{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"The last few years have brought record-breaking fires. Scientists predict that this trend is likely to continue as the world warms. However, predicting exactly how the future of wildfires will affect people and their communities, and change our wild landscape, is much more complicated. 

In some locations, land managers are using smaller controlled burns to help prevent larger wildfires as they act as a kind of incendiary rake, clearing out grasses, shrubs and other plant matter before they become fuel for bigger more intense fires.

**Some scientists are also suggesting that nature might respond in a way that isn’t as obvious. Once wildfires have burnt through forested areas, the cycle of forest succession may not continue. It may be too dry and hot for trees to grow. Smaller fires may burn vegetation before it has the chance to fully mature. If this prediction is correct, wildfires that are followed by drought may change forested landscapes into prairie land, which is an entirely different ecosystem.**
","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

embeddables.content:
The process of plants and trees growing back after a wildfire is called forest succession. The graphic below depicts the process of typical forest succession.

Scientists say that it takes over 50 years for trees to fully grow back after a fire!

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"","teacherTip":"Forest succession does not just include vegetation. Fungi, birds, insects, and animals all rely on trees and vegetation for their habitat. There is also a cycle to which organisms return first. For more information about forest succession, see Wikipedia and this link. ","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"stickyNote"}}

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"After a fire, plants and trees grow back in a predictable way. First, grasses and other plants grow back. Then, small bushes and trees begin to grow as well. Next, fast growing evergreen trees develop to their fullest, while shade-tolerant trees develop underneath. Finally, deciduous trees grow over the shade intolerant trees and vegetation, returning the ecosystem back to a similar state from where it began.","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

{"version":1,"url":"https://has-production.s3.amazonaws.com/resources/geohazard-wildfire/Secondary_SuccessionFire.png","caption":"An example of Secondary Succession by stages:
1. An area of growth
2. A disturbance, such as a fire, destroys the forest
3. The fire burns the forest to the ground
4. The fire leaves behind empty, but not destroyed soil
5. Grasses and other herbaceous plants grow back first
6. Small bushes and trees begin to colonize the public area
7. Fast growing evergreen trees and bamboo trees develop to their fullest, while shade-tolerant trees develop in the understory
8. The short-lived and shade intolerant evergreen trees die as the larger deciduous trees overtop them. The ecosystem is now back to a similar state to where it began.","credit":"Katelyn Murphy/Wikipedia Commons","creditLink":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secondary_succession#/media/File:Secondary_Succession.png","creditLinkDisplayText":"","allowLightbox":true}

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"discussionPoints","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"Climate change is also changing the cycle of forest succession. This is because trees have a harder time growing back in warm and low moisture areas. This makes way for more shrubs and grasses, both of which are very effective competitors for moisture. Sometimes, if a fire is large enough, new seeds cannot get to the middle of the burned area and it will be devoid of vegetation for a long time. In very intense fires, heat from the fire can penetrate into the deepest layers of the soil and destroy the microbiome needed to sustain healthy plant growth.

This is a good time to stop the class and ask students the following questions to generate discussion:

** Should humans help plant new seeds to get forests to grow back faster and denser? Why or why not?**

** Scientists use prescribed burns to eliminate excess debris, but it also burns down living vegetation. Why are prescribed burns different than a real wildfire? Do you think prescribed burns are good for the environment?**

** Which organisms do you think come back first after a fire along with grasses and shrubs?**

**What happens to an ecosystem when most of the vegetation burns and there isn't enough time for it to fully grow back before to the next wildfire strikes?**
","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"If the climate continues to warm, some species of trees will struggle to grow in their usual locations. They will grow slowly, and other species of trees that are better suited to grow in warm conditions will move in and take over. Additionally, if fires are frequent, the ecosystem will not be able to move past the middle stages of succession, meaning some forests will never have the time to grow back fully as they were before fires came in.","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

embeddables.content:
Depending on where people live and environmental conditions, wildfire risks and impacts will change over the next 100 years.

As towns and cities grow, the demand for housing grows as well. Often the area left to build more houses is on the edge of the city, close to forests and other wild areas. Remember the Fire Triangle? Wild areas contain a lot of fuel! 

Santa Fe, New Mexico is a growing city in the southwest United States. The city is shown in the map by the large grey area in the center. Scientists used a model to create the wildfire risk map of the city. The redder the area on the map, the greater the wildfire risk.

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"discussionPoints","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"Now that you are at the end of the module, have the students complete their Summary Table. Have them look across activities, identify patterns, and think about how these patterns can be brought together to create an explanation for the guiding question: **How will wildfire risks and impacts change over the next 100 years?** Provide time for the students to generate answers to the question (as individuals or as a group), share their explanations with others in a peer review format, and finally generate a whole class explanation. To help with gathering the essential elements of their explanation, you can create a Gotta Have List. Now is the time to talk about risks and impacts in the future. Questions that might stimulate class discussion include: * What are some changes we are seeing in the near term (more intense wildfires, more severe hazards) and are they being caused by climate change? * What effect will more weather extremes (higher and lower precipitations, increasing temperatures, etc) have on the risks and impacts of wildfires? * What are the uncertainties involved in making predictions about the severity of future risks and impacts? * What role does mitigation play in the frequency and intensity of future wildfires?","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

activities.description:
Hello, students!

We would like to hear what you thought about the Wildfire Module. Please answer the questions in this activity thoughtfully and honestly. Your feedback will be used to help revise the module for future students.

Thank you!
